articles.snippet: The three-time Stanley Cup champion is a fan of Joovv lights, ashwaganda herbs, PoV Sport and Lululemon.
articles.lead_paragraph: Duncan Keith, 35, is a three-time Stanley Cup champion and Conn Smythe Trophy winner, who recently played his 1,000th professional hockey game, all with the Chicago Blackhawks. A small-town guy at heart, he splits his time between Chicago and Penticton, British Columbia, where he grew up.
articles.abstract: The three-time Stanley Cup champion is a fan of Joovv lights, ashwaganda herbs, PoV Sport and Lululemon.

headline.main: Why N.H.L. Player Duncan Keith Calls Himself a Biohacker
headline.print_headline: N.H.L.’s Duncan Keith Calls Himself a Biohacker

articles.snippet: The Kings, the Ducks and the Blackhawks dominated the Western Conference in the past 10 years. But they have been left behind as the league has evolved.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — From 2009 to 2018, the Los Angeles Kings, the Anaheim Ducks and the Chicago Blackhawks combined for nine trips to the Western Conference finals and five Stanley Cups.
articles.abstract: The Kings, the Ducks and the Blackhawks dominated the Western Conference in the past 10 years. But they have been left behind as the league has evolved.

headline.main: Longtime N.H.L. Powers Adjust to the View From the Bottom
headline.print_headline: Longtime Powers Adjust to the View From the Bottom

articles.snippet: Chasing its first Cup, San Jose added the star defenseman Erik Karlsson in the off-season and boasted as much versatility and depth as the franchise has ever had.
articles.lead_paragraph: The San Jose Sharks’ season began with soaring expectations. Perennial contenders, they had added the star defenseman Erik Karlsson in the off-season and boasted as much talent, versatility, balance and depth as they ever had in their 27 N.H.L. seasons.
articles.abstract: Chasing its first Cup, San Jose added the star defenseman Erik Karlsson in the off-season and boasted as much versatility and depth as the franchise has ever had.

headline.main: The Sharks Went All In for a Stanley Cup. Just Don’t Tell Them That.
headline.print_headline: Championship Window Closing? Sharks Still Feel a Breeze

articles.snippet: Hagelin, who has spent time on three teams this season, has been involved in eliminating Washington from the playoffs five times, three as a Ranger, two as a Penguin.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Washington Capitals right winger Carl Hagelin is a two-time Stanley Cup champion and has appeared in more playoff games than any other N.H.L. player since his postseason debut seven years ago.
articles.abstract: Hagelin, who has spent time on three teams this season, has been involved in eliminating Washington from the playoffs five times, three as a Ranger, two as a Penguin.

headline.main: Carl Hagelin Made a Habit of Knocking Off the Capitals. Now He Is One of Them.
headline.print_headline: He Kept Spoiling the Caps’ Playoffs, So They Hired Him

articles.snippet: Upsets abounded in the first round of the Stanley Cup playoffs. Here are the matchups for the second round.
articles.lead_paragraph: Here are the matchups for the second round of the Stanley Cup playoffs. All Times Eastern. (Series are best-of-seven; x-if necessary.)
articles.abstract: Upsets abounded in the first round of the Stanley Cup playoffs. Here are the matchups for the second round.

headline.main: N.H.L. Playoffs: Second-Round Schedule and Results

articles.snippet: The first round will be remembered for surprises. The roots of the upsets were in off-season moves and trade deadline strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sure, some predictable things happened in the first round of the N.H.L. playoffs — like the Toronto Maple Leafs again failing to advance. They have not won a postseason series since 2004, and their Stanley Cup drought has reached 51 seasons. With the three Canadian playoff teams eliminated, the Cup will go to an American franchise for the 26th straight year.
articles.abstract: The first round will be remembered for surprises. The roots of the upsets were in off-season moves and trade deadline strategy.

headline.main: N.H.L. Playoffs: All the Right Moves
headline.print_headline: Moves That Helped Set Up the First-Round Upsets

articles.snippet: A fierce but seldom penalized Hall of Famer, he helped capture eight N.H.L. titles — four with the Red Wings and four with the Maple Leafs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Red Kelly, the Hockey Hall of Famer who helped propel the Detroit Red Wings to four Stanley Cup championships as a defenseman and the Toronto Maple Leafs to another four N.H.L. titles while playing at center, died on Thursday in Toronto. He was 91.
articles.abstract: A fierce but seldom penalized Hall of Famer, he helped capture eight N.H.L. titles — four with the Red Wings and four with the Maple Leafs.

headline.main: Red Kelly, Gentleman Stalwart in a Run of Stanley Cups, Is Dead at 91
headline.print_headline: Red Kelly, Gentleman Stalwart in a Run of Stanley Cups, Is Dead at 91

articles.snippet: After a double-overtime victory on Tuesday night in a Game 7, the Blues are in the conference finals, with the elusive Stanley Cup Finals within reach.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are plenty of candidates for longest suffering American sports fans. Chicago Cubs fans held the title by acclamation until the World Series win of 2016. The Seattle Mariners have the longest streak without postseason play. The Buffalo Bills get sympathy for their four straight Super Bowl losses.
articles.abstract: After a double-overtime victory on Tuesday night in a Game 7, the Blues are in the conference finals, with the elusive Stanley Cup Finals within reach.

headline.main: St. Louis Blues Give Long-Suffering Fans Reason to Believe

articles.snippet: The St. Louis Blues are the only “Expansion Six” team left without a Stanley Cup. The San Jose Sharks came later, but have endured similar heartbreak.
articles.lead_paragraph: The San Jose Sharks and the St. Louis Blues, who will square off in Game 1 of the N.H.L.’s Western Conference finals Saturday, are each in pursuit of their first Stanley Cup. The only player on either team who has won a Cup is Sharks goalie Martin Jones, a backup for the Los Angeles Kings in 2014.
articles.abstract: The St. Louis Blues are the only “Expansion Six” team left without a Stanley Cup. The San Jose Sharks came later, but have endured similar heartbreak.

headline.main: In the Western Conference, Teams Known for Heartbreak Seek Glory
headline.print_headline: In the West, Two Teams Seeking a First Cup Title

articles.snippet: The pipeline of American hockey, which snakes from Massachusetts west into Michigan and Minnesota, has meandered south, to Missouri.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Scott Rupp flipped open the red spiral notebook he keeps as president of the St. Louis Amateur Hockey Hall of Fame and ran his index finger down the inside cover, along a column of surnames and birthdays that swells every year. Written in neat blue penmanship, they represent players who grew up in the area and have appeared in the N.H.L.
articles.abstract: The pipeline of American hockey, which snakes from Massachusetts west into Michigan and Minnesota, has meandered south, to Missouri.

headline.main: As the Blues Seek the Stanley Cup, a Hockey Hub Grows in St. Louis
headline.print_headline: Thanks to the Blues, a Hotbed Springs Up in St. Louis

articles.snippet: Ranked 22nd in the world, the British have yet to win a game in this year’s world hockey championships. But ice hockey has grown in Britain.
articles.lead_paragraph: KOSICE, Slovakia — The N.H.L.’s best teams may be competing for a cup named after an Englishman — Lord Stanley, a governor general of Canada who has been dead for over a century — but the ties between Britain and the sport’s highest levels usually end there.
articles.abstract: Ranked 22nd in the world, the British have yet to win a game in this year’s world hockey championships. But ice hockey has grown in Britain.

headline.main: Britannia Rules the … Rink? Maybe One Day
headline.print_headline: Britannia Rules the … Rink? Maybe One Day

articles.snippet: On Jan. 3, St. Louis had the worst record in the N.H.L. On Tuesday, the Blues became the Western Conference champions.
articles.lead_paragraph: The St. Louis Blues, the N.H.L.’s worst team as late as the morning of Jan. 3, are four wins from hoisting their first Stanley Cup. They advanced to the final round for the first time in 49 years on Tuesday night, ousting the San Jose Sharks from the Western Conference finals with a 5-1 victory in St. Louis.
articles.abstract: On Jan. 3, St. Louis had the worst record in the N.H.L. On Tuesday, the Blues became the Western Conference champions.

headline.main: How the Blues Went From Last Place to the Stanley Cup Finals
headline.print_headline: How the Blues Became Happy

articles.snippet: As a goalie, Davidson came up just short of winning a Stanley Cup in New York. Now, he will try to bring a championship as team president.
articles.lead_paragraph: John Davidson stepped behind a lectern emblazoned with the Rangers logo on Wednesday and got straight to the point.
articles.abstract: As a goalie, Davidson came up just short of winning a Stanley Cup in New York. Now, he will try to bring a championship as team president.

headline.main: Back With the Rangers, John Davidson Has Unfinished Business
headline.print_headline: As Davidson Rejoins Rangers, ‘This Far’ Is Too Far From the Cup

articles.snippet: Boston will seek its seventh N.H.L. championship, while St. Louis pursues its first.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Stanley Cup finals, set to begin Monday, are a rematch 49 years in the making. The Boston Bruins and the St. Louis Blues will meet for the N.H.L. championship for the first time since 1970, when an overtime, series-winning goal by Boston defenseman Bobby Orr became one of the most memorable moments in hockey history. He was tripped during the shot and flew through the air as the puck entered the net — a statue of Orr scoring that goal stands outside TD Garden, where Game 1 of the finals will be played.
articles.abstract: Boston will seek its seventh N.H.L. championship, while St. Louis pursues its first.

headline.main: Stanley Cup Finals Preview: Bruins and Blues Flash Back to 1970
headline.print_headline: ‘Hardest, Heaviest Teams’ Meet as Perennial Contender and Outsider

articles.snippet: At 42, Chara is 14 years older than Boston’s next oldest defenseman, and he will be seeking his second title with the Bruins when the Stanley Cup finals start on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — At 42, Zdeno Chara is 14 years older than the next oldest Bruins defenseman, Torey Krug.
articles.abstract: At 42, Chara is 14 years older than Boston’s next oldest defenseman, and he will be seeking his second title with the Bruins when the Stanley Cup finals start on Monday.

headline.main: Mentoring His Much Younger Bruins Teammates Is Vintage Zdeno Chara
headline.print_headline: Young Bruins Look Up to the Old Man on the Ice

articles.snippet: Goalie Jordan Binnington, a 25-year-old rookie, was not part of the Blues’ “master plan.” But he stabilized a team careering out of contention.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Before becoming an improbable catalyst for the St. Louis Blues’ improbable stampede to the Stanley Cup finals, Jordan Binnington had the coolest goalie mask in the E.C.H.L.
articles.abstract: Goalie Jordan Binnington, a 25-year-old rookie, was not part of the Blues’ “master plan.” But he stabilized a team careering out of contention.

headline.main: How a Fourth-String Goalie Led the Blues to the Stanley Cup Finals
headline.print_headline: This Is a Story All About How the Blues Got Flipped Upside-Down

articles.snippet: The Bruins were down 2-0 but ended up with 4-2 win over St. Louis that puts them three wins from a Stanley Cup.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Torey Krug flew down the ice with his helmet off, like his big, bad predecessors on the Boston defense from the days of Eddie Shore and Bobby Orr.
articles.abstract: The Bruins were down 2-0 but ended up with 4-2 win over St. Louis that puts them three wins from a Stanley Cup.

articles.snippet: Carl Gunnarsson scored 3:51 into overtime to give St. Louis a 3-2 win over Boston and tie the finals at a game apiece.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Blues defenseman Carl Gunnarsson bumped into Coach Craig Berube in the bathroom before the start of overtime and told him: “I just need one more.”
articles.abstract: Carl Gunnarsson scored 3:51 into overtime to give St. Louis a 3-2 win over Boston and tie the finals at a game apiece.

headline.main: Blues Beat the Bruins and Get Their First Stanley Cup Finals Victory
headline.print_headline: Blues Notch First Finals Victory

articles.snippet: The Bay State’s teams have won several championships in the 21st century, but unlike the others, a title by the Bruins this year would mean a duck boat parade with some hometown heroes.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The Bruins are two victories in the Stanley Cup finals from extending Boston’s reign of championship gluttony — 12 titles in an 18-year stretch that reached full-bloom obnoxiousness in February with, yawn, yet another Patriots triumph in the Super Bowl.
articles.abstract: The Bay State’s teams have won several championships in the 21st century, but unlike the others, a title by the Bruins this year would mean a duck boat parade with some hometown heroes.

headline.main: Boston’s Latest Would-Be Champs Are Truly Boston’s
headline.print_headline: In These Bruins, Boston Gets Some True Hometown Heroes

articles.snippet: After 19 years of singing the national anthem at Blues games, Charles Glenn is retiring because his multiple sclerosis commands more of his attention.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — The bad days used to come once a month for Charles Glenn, but now they bedevil him every two weeks or so. When they do, he can’t feel his legs or his hands, or get dressed. His memory meanders and leaves him grasping for names and dates and thoughts.
articles.abstract: After 19 years of singing the national anthem at Blues games, Charles Glenn is retiring because his multiple sclerosis commands more of his attention.

headline.main: With or Without a Stanley Cup, the Blues Will Lose Their Voice
headline.print_headline: ‘Gloria’ Is a Theme Song. The Anthem Is an Inspiration.

articles.snippet: An official appeared to miss a penalty by a St. Louis Blues player, setting off a sequence that allowed them to score the decisive goal in a 2-1 victory over the Boston Bruins.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — With his St. Louis Blues leading the Boston Bruins by a goal midway through the third period of a pivotal game in a tied Stanley Cup finals, Tyler Bozak tripped Noel Acciari.
articles.abstract: An official appeared to miss a penalty by a St. Louis Blues player, setting off a sequence that allowed them to score the decisive goal in a 2-1 victory over the Boston Bruins.

headline.main: Blues Beat Bruins, but Officiating Takes Center Stage at Stanley Cup Finals
headline.print_headline: An Unwelcome Spotlight on Officiating

articles.snippet: Needing to survive an elimination game on the road in St. Louis, Boston led for most of the game and ended up with a blowout.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — The final thing the Boston Bruins saw before leaving their locker room at Enterprise Center was a keepsake from eight years ago. A framed photograph hanging above the exit showed Patrice Bergeron clutching a bottle of Champagne, his mouth open in delight, as Brad Marchand, standing to his right, held the Stanley Cup aloft.
articles.abstract: Needing to survive an elimination game on the road in St. Louis, Boston led for most of the game and ended up with a blowout.

headline.main: Stanley Cup Finals Headed to Game 7 After Bruins Wallop Blues
headline.print_headline: The Bruins, Using a Past Comeback as Their Touchstone, Force Game 7

articles.snippet: Confusion reigned over the Stanley Cup when the Bruins notched their first N.H.L. title. During a transition from an old era to a new one, Boston claimed a double win.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Boston Bruins claimed their first Stanley Cup in Montreal on a Saturday night in March 1929, sweeping aside the mighty Canadiens. Back home, a crowd of 3,000 met the team’s train at North Station.
articles.abstract: Confusion reigned over the Stanley Cup when the Bruins notched their first N.H.L. title. During a transition from an old era to a new one, Boston claimed a double win.

headline.main: When the Boston Bruins Won Their First Stanley Cup. Twice.

articles.snippet: They’re usually low-scoring. Home teams have the edge. Overtime is even rarer. The spectacle of Game 7 of the Stanley Cup finals awaits Boston and St. Louis.
articles.lead_paragraph: The name alone is enough to make the ice sparkle a little brighter: Game 7 of the Stanley Cup finals. It’s what children conjure on rinks and ponds as they imagine themselves to be Penguins or Oilers or Golden Knights.
articles.abstract: They’re usually low-scoring. Home teams have the edge. Overtime is even rarer. The spectacle of Game 7 of the Stanley Cup finals awaits Boston and St. Louis.

headline.main: A Stanley Cup Game 7 Looms. They Don’t Happen Often.
headline.print_headline: The Spectacle on Ice: It’s Winner Take All

articles.snippet: St. Louis sat in last place in the N.H.L. standings on Jan. 3 and then beat the Boston Bruins in the Cup finals, soaring to the first championship in the franchise’s history.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — When their proximity to the inconceivable can be measured in months or years instead of mere days or weeks, the members of the St. Louis Blues will reflect upon one of the most extraordinary moments of not only their lives, or the team’s 52 years in the N.H.L., but also the two and a half centuries since a pair of fur traders settled the city along the western banks of the Mississippi River.
articles.abstract: St. Louis sat in last place in the N.H.L. standings on Jan. 3 and then beat the Boston Bruins in the Cup finals, soaring to the first championship in the franchise’s history.

headline.main: St. Louis Blues Claim the Stanley Cup, Ending a 52-Year Wait
headline.kicker: Blues 4, Bruins 1 | St. Louis wins series, 4-3.
headline.print_headline: The Blues Never Felt So Good

articles.snippet: Longest championship droughts? Now it’s Toronto, Vancouver and Buffalo in the N.H.L.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the St. Louis Blues defeated the Bruins in Game 7 of the Stanley Cup finals in Boston on Wednesday night, it was the team’s first title. After the 4-1 win, Blues fans celebrated a championship they had been waiting for since coming into the N.H.L. in 1967. A year ago, the Washington Capitals, in the league since 1974, also lifted the Cup for the first time.
articles.abstract: Longest championship droughts? Now it’s Toronto, Vancouver and Buffalo in the N.H.L.

headline.main: St. Louis Celebrates, Leaving Other Cities to Sing the Title Drought Blues
headline.print_headline: St. Louis Celebrates, Leaving Other Cities Singing the Blues

articles.snippet: Is Canada, the land of hockey, moving toward basketball?
articles.lead_paragraph: It was, to understate things greatly, an atypical sports week in Canada. When the St. Louis Blues, a team dominated by Canadian players, won its first Stanley Cup on Wednesday after 52 years, the result was almost an afterthought in many sports reports.
articles.abstract: Is Canada, the land of hockey, moving toward basketball?

headline.main: The Raptors’ Rise Focuses Canadians on a Different Net

articles.snippet: The N.H.L. season begins Wednesday, with top players and coaches in new places and another infusion on young talent.
articles.lead_paragraph: The N.H.L. season begins Wednesday, when the last two champions — the St. Louis Blues and the Washington Capitals — square off in St. Louis. The most exciting developments of a season are seldom predictable. An expansion team from Las Vegas reached the finals two years ago. St. Louis went from last-place malaise to Stanley Cup glory, winning its first championship after 50-plus years in the league. The Tampa Bay Lightning were a playoff bust after a peerless regular season.
articles.abstract: The N.H.L. season begins Wednesday, with top players and coaches in new places and another infusion on young talent.

headline.main: N.H.L. Preview: Five Story Lines to Watch This Season
headline.print_headline: Before the Puck Drops: Learning the Three R’s

articles.snippet: Quenneville, who won three championships in Chicago, was hired by the Panthers to coach them out of mediocrity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joel Quenneville wanted to make it clear: He did not take the job as coach of the Florida Panthers because  he wanted to be closer to South Florida’s many golf courses.
articles.abstract: Quenneville, who won three championships in Chicago, was hired by the Panthers to coach them out of mediocrity.

headline.main: Joel Quenneville Brings His Stanley Cup Pedigree to Florida
headline.print_headline: Coach’s Pedigree Commands Respect in Florida

articles.abstract: The season already has its share of surprises, even if the past four weeks might not say much about how it all ends.
articles.snippet: The season already has its share of surprises, even if the past four weeks might not say much about how it all ends.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the past decade in the N.H.L., the Flyers have qualified for the playoffs in the last game of a season and reached the finals. The Kings have squeaked into the playoffs and then won not one but two Stanley Cups in three years. Just last season, the Blues were in last place in January before ascending to their first Stanley Cup, ending more a wait that extended more than 50 years.

headline.main: Takeaways From the First Month of the N.H.L. Season
headline.print_headline: First Month of the N.H.L. Season Has Served Up Plenty of Surprises

byline.original: By Andrew Knoll and Allan Kreda

articles.abstract: Babcock has won a Stanley Cup and Olympic gold medals, but he could not end Toronto’s championship drought.
articles.snippet: Babcock has won a Stanley Cup and Olympic gold medals, but he could not end Toronto’s championship drought.
articles.lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The underperforming Toronto Maple Leafs fired Coach Mike Babcock on Wednesday and replaced him with Sheldon Keefe.

headline.main: Maple Leafs Fire Coach Mike Babcock
